"https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=320&h=260&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "8" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=320&h=180&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "9" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=485&h=273&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "10" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=650&h=356&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "11" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=815&h=458&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "12" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=ap&w=980&h=551&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "13" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=0&h=366&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "14" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=ap&w=220&h=0&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "15" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=532&h=532&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "16" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=1280&h=720&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "200" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=200&h=200&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "400" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/primary-trop.jpg?v=at&w=400&h=400&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0"} , "body" : "<p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>An area of disturbed weather near the Bahamas may become a tropical or subtropical depression or storm later this week, and may soak parts of the Southeast coast during the Memorial Day weekend.</p><p>On Wednesday morning, the <a href=\"http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/gtwo.php?basin=atlc&fdays=5\">National Hurricane Center (NHC</a>) said that this system now has a 50 percent chance of developing into a subtropical or tropical depression or storm in the next five days. This is a slight increase in odds for development from an earlier outlook issued Tuesday.</p><p>In addition, the area of interest has also been designated as Invest 91-L by the NHC.  This naming convention is used by the NHC to identify features they are monitoring for potential future development into a depression or storm.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/what-is-an-invest-20120815\">What is an Invest?</a>)</strong></p><p>Here's what we know right now.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/2016-hurricane-season-forecast-atlantic-the-weather-channel\">Atlantic Hurricane Season Forecast</a>)</strong></p><h3><strong>Tropical or Subtropical Development Factors</strong></h3><p>To kick off the feedback mechanism forming a tropical cyclone, you need sufficient thunderstorms to cluster and persist near an area of surface low pressure.</p><p>In the last day or so, we've seen thunderstorm activity bubble up near the central and southeast Bahamas. This activity is currently to the southeast of the area that the NHC has highlighted for possible development.</p><p><div id=\"wxn1\" /></p><p>However, those thunderstorms are being instigated, in part, by a strong southward plunge of the jet stream and its associated lift in the atmosphere. These strong winds aloft won't allow thunderstorms to cluster in any one area.</p><p>That may change late in the week as the storminess moves towards the Southeast coast. Winds aloft are beginning to decrease in the area of interest and could become more favorable for development in 24 to 48 hours.</p><p>A leftover frontal boundary may serve as a focus for converging air to focus thunderstorm activity, a common culprit for tropical development early in the hurricane season.</p><p>The combination of the above ingredients may eventually lead to the aforementioned development of the surface low pressure system that is required for a subtropical or tropical system to develop. As of Wednesday afternoon, there were signs that a surface low pressure system may be taking shape, but it was mostly devoid of thunderstorm activity.</p><p>While most computer model forecast guidance depicts that a low pressure system will move toward the area highlighted for development by NHC, there remains questions about how well organized it will be.</p><h3><strong>What is the Upshot of All of This?</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn2\" /></p><p>No matter whether a tropical or subtropical depression or storm develops or not, there will likely be some impacts along the Southeast coast.</p><p>Those impacts will mostly be increased rainfall and the potential for rip currents and high surf for parts of the Southeast coast during the Memorial Day weekend.</p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/travel/commuter-conditions/news/memorial-day-weekend-travel-forecast-2016\">Holiday Weekend Outlook</a></strong>)</p><p>If you have plans to hit the beach along the Southeast coast this holiday weekend, we don't suggest canceling plans yet. Check back with us at weather.com. We will continue to watch this situation closely, and will provide updates over the next few days.</p><p><div id=\"wxn3\" /></p><p>(<strong>FORECAST: <a href=\"/weather/holiday/memorial-day//l/USVA0797:1:US\">Virginia Beach</a> | <a href=\"/weather/holiday/memorial-day//l/USNC0301:1:US\">Hatteras</a> | <a href=\"/weather/holiday/memorial-day//l/USSC0239:1:US\">Myrtle Beach</a> | <a href=\"/weather/holiday/memorial-day//l/USFL0106:1:US\">Daytona Beach</a></strong>)</p><p>The next named storm of the 2016 Atlantic Hurricane Season will be given the name Bonnie.</p><p>If you recall, we already had the Ã¢ÂÂAÃ¢ÂÂ named storm this season. <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-alex-atlantic-ocean-azores\">Hurricane Alex</a> was a rare January storm that formed in the eastern Atlantic Ocean and impacted the Azores.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/safety/hurricane/news/florida-hurricane-drought-may2016\">Florida's Lucky Hurricane Drought</a>)</strong></p><h3><strong>Southeast Coast is Typically an Early Season Area to Watch</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn4\" /></p><p>The area off the Southeast coast, as well as the Gulf of Mexico and northwest Caribbean, is a part of the Atlantic basin where early-season tropical or subtropical storm development is most likely.</p><p>That said, it's not a very active time of year for storms to form compared to the peak August-October period. For example, only one named storm forms during June every other year, on average.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/june-hurricanes-tropical-storms-formation-locations\">Where June Storms Develop</a>)</strong></p><p>Recent seasons have had activity before the start of June.</p><p>Last May, <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/tropical-storm-ana-atlantic-hurricane-season\">Tropical Storm Ana</a> formed off the Southeast coast before making landfall near Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, with minor impacts.</p><p>In 2012 two named storms, Alberto and Beryl, formed during May off the Southeast coast. Beryl would go on to make landfall in northeast Florida, while Alberto moved out to sea.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-season-begins-before-june-1\">When Hurricane Season Starts Early</a>)</strong></p><h3><strong>Difference Between Subtropical and Tropical Storms</strong></h3><p>A subtropical depression or storm exhibits features of both tropical and non-tropical systems, with a broad wind field, no cold or warm fronts, and generally low-topped thunderstorms spaced some distance from the center.</p><p>Subtropical cyclones typically are associated with upper-level lows and have colder temperatures aloft, whereas tropical cyclones are fully warm-core, and upper-level high-pressure systems overhead help facilitate their intensification.</p><p>Because of this hybrid nature, the National Hurricane Center still issues advisories and forecasts (i.e. projected path) for subtropical depressions and storms and assigns a number or name much like a regular tropical depression or tropical storm.</p><p>Occasionally, if thunderstorms cluster close enough and persist near the center, latent heat given off aloft from the thunderstorms can warm the air enough to make the storm a fully tropical storm.</p><p>When that happens, the wind field will tighten closer to the center. Of course, this would also open the door to further intensification.</p><h3>MORE ON WEATHER.COM: Hurricanes From Space - Satellite Imagery</h3><p><div id=\"wxn5\" /></p>" , "flags" : { "Facebook" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/trump3.jpg?v=at&w=400&h=400&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0"} , "body" : "<p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>Donald Trump wants to build a sea wall to protect a golf course he owns in Ireland from erosion caused by global warming.</p><p>It may be a sound business decision, but itÃ¢ÂÂs a 180-degree swing for the Republican presidential candidate, who has repeatedly called talk of global warming and climate change a hoax.</p><p><div id=\"wxn1\" /></p><p>In an application filed this month in County Clare, Ireland, the Trump International Golf Links and Hotel cites the threat of global warming in seeking a permit to build a nearly two-mile-long stone wall between it and the Atlantic Ocean. The beach in front of the 18th green is disappearing at a rate of about a yard each year.</p><p>\"Donald Trump clearly cares more about the fate of his golf courses than the health of the millions of families already affected by the climate crisis,\" said Adam Beitman, a spokesman for the Sierra Club.</p><p>Trump's application, first reported Monday by Politico, cites local regulations pertaining to \"<a href=\"http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/donald-trump-climate-change-golf-course-223436#ixzz49UO4jkzY\" target=\"_blank\">rising sea levels and increased storm frequency and wave energy associated with global warming</a>.\" An attached environmental impact statement says that almost all the dunes in western Ireland are retreating \"due to sea level rise and increased Atlantic storminess.\"</p><p>Ã¢ÂÂIt's diabolical,\" former South Carolina Republican Rep. Bob Inglis, an advocate of conservative solutions to climate change, told Politico. Ã¢ÂÂDonald Trump is working to ensure his at-risk properties and his company is trying to figure out how to deal with sea level rise. Meanwhile, heÃ¢ÂÂs saying things to audiences that he must know are not true. Ã¢ÂÂ¦ You have a soft place in your heart for people who are honestly ignorant, but people who are deceitful, thatÃ¢ÂÂs a different thing.Ã¢ÂÂ</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"https://weather.com/news/climate/news/portland-school-district-bans-climate-change-denying-materials\" target=\"_blank\">Portland School System Bans Teaching Materials That Cast Doubt on Climate Change</a>)</strong></p><p>TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs sea wall application calls out an Irish government study for failing to account for the effects of climate change on coastal erosion, Politico reports.</p><p>Ã¢ÂÂIn our view, it could reasonably be expected that the rate of sea level rise might become twice of that presently occurring. Ã¢ÂÂ¦ As a result, we would expect the rate of dune recession to increase.Ã¢ÂÂ</p><p>TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs company is also using the threat of climate change to increase support for the sea wall among local residents, Politico reports. An appendix to the application includes a scan of a brochure that the company has distributed to residents. One of included bullet points states: \"Predicted sea level rise and more frequent storm events will increase the rate of erosion throughout the 21st century.\"</p><p>Trump has repeatedly taken to Twitter to express skepticism that human activity is causing the world to warm, raising sea levels as the polar ice caps melt. He has also said he would seek to \"renegotiate\" the global accord to cut climate-warming carbon emissions agreed to by President Barack Obama in December.<br><br><div id=\"wxn2\" /><br><div id=\"wxn3\" /><br><div id=\"wxn4\" /><br><br>Ã¢ÂÂAny and all weather events are used by the <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/427556692109574146?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\">GLOBAL WARMING HOAXSTERS</a> to justify higher taxes to save our planet! They don't believe it $$$$!Ã¢ÂÂ Trump tweeted in 2014.</p><p>\"The entire country is FREEZING - we desperately need a heavy dose of global warming, and fast! Ice caps size reaches all-time high,\" Trump he said that same year. </p><p>In an interview with Reuters earlier this month, Trump said he would <a href=\"http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-climate-exclusive-idUSKCN0Y82NW?mod=related&channelName=politicsNews\" target=\"_blank\">renegotiate AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs role in the U.N. global climate accord</a> reached last year in Paris.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"https://weather.com/news/climate/news/catastrophic-climate-change-one-of-greatest-threats-to-earth\" target=\"_blank\">Catastrophic Climate Change Makes List of Mankind's Most Serious Threats</a>)</strong></p><p>\"I will be looking at that very, very seriously, and at a minimum I will be renegotiating those agreements, at a minimum. And at a maximum I may do something else,\" he told Reuters. Ã¢ÂÂBut those agreements are one-sided agreements and they are bad for the United States.\"</p><p>Trump campaign spokesman Alan Garten did not respond Monday to messages from The Associated Press seeking comment.</p><p><strong>MORE ON WEATHER.COM: Islands We're Losing to Rising Sea Levels </strong></p><p><div id=\"wxn5\" /></p>" , "flags" : { "Facebook" : true , "Intranet" : false , "TV App" : false , "Twitter" : true , "YouTube" : true , "Google+" : true , "Big Web" : true , "Little Web" : true , "Mobile Apps" : true , "orig_source" : "Reboot"} , "wxnodes" : [ { "id" : "wxn0" , "schema_version" : "1.1.12" , "type" : "wxnode_video" , "align" : "" , "options" : [ "show_descriptions"] , "assetid" : "" , "clipid" : "98844620-1e99-42ed-a72d-daa667377458" , "collection" : "" , "collection_name" : "" , "playlist_type" : "assets"} , { "id" : "wxn1" , "type" : "wxnode_internal_image" , "links" : [ ] , "align" : "left" , "assetid" : "aeb94f9c-7323-4ab0-a9a5-c3d7e7e9b07a" , "sizecode" : "inset" , "credit" : "Danny Lawson/PA Wire " , "linkurl" : "" , "synopsis" : "In this file photo, Donald Trump speaks at the Trump International Golf Links in Aberdeenshire, Ireland. "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/stormy_late_wk_setup3_copy_0.jpg?v=at&w=532&h=532&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "16" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/stormy_late_wk_setup3_copy_0.jpg?v=at&w=1280&h=720&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "200" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/stormy_late_wk_setup3_copy_0.jpg?v=at&w=200&h=200&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "400" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/stormy_late_wk_setup3_copy_0.jpg?v=at&w=400&h=400&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0"} , "body" : "<p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>Supercell thunderstorms spawned a swarm of tornadoes over western Kansas and in parts of four other states Tuesday, and more severe weather is on the way the next several days in the nation's heartland.</p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/storms/severe/news/severe-storms-plains-midwest\">Latest Damage Reports Recap</a></strong>)</p><p>Over two dozen reports of tornadoes were received by the National Weather Service (NWS) Tuesday.</p><p>Dodge City, Kansas, had a very close call from a slow-moving supercell that spawned tornadoes southwest, west, and north of the city. Storm surveys have begun, and preliminary evidence supports an EF3 rating for the tornado south-southwest of Dodge City according to the NWS . At times, there were two tornadoes in progress at once from that cyclical supercell. Surveys will continue into the afternoon. </p><p><div id=\"wxn1\" /></p><p>There were reports of a house being damaged east of Ensign, Kansas. Fortunately, the occupants of the home were said to be fine.<font color=\"#393939\" face=\"Open Sans, Helvetica Neue, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif\"><span style=\"font-size: 14px; line-height: 21px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);\"> </span></font>After the tornado had passed, damage was reported on the west side of Dodge City, as well as a propane leak on the highway which blocked traffic.</p><p>For more on Tuesday's storm reports, scroll down to our storm reports section or <a href=\"/storms/severe/news/severe-storms-plains-midwest\">click here to read our impacts article</a>.</p><p>The rounds of thunderstorms this week are being triggered by ripples of energy ejecting eastward from a southward dip in the jet stream across the West.</p><p>That upper-level energy is intercepting a warm, humid air mass being pulled north from the Gulf of Mexico, allowing the thunderstorms to form.</p><p><div id=\"wxn2\" /></p><p><div id=\"wxn3\" /></p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/weather/map/interactive/l/MCI:9:US?layers=0123,0039&zoom=4&baseMap=r\">View National Interactive Radar Map</a> | </strong><strong><a href=\"/safety/thunderstorms/news/watch-vs-warning-whats-difference-20140409\">Difference Between a Watch and a Warning</a>)</strong></p><p>Below is our latest forecast thinking on the timing and magnitude of this severe weather event throughout the next several days.</p><h3><strong>Severe Weather Forecast</strong></h3><p>Keep in mind that although our forecasts maps the next several days may show that a large area is at risk for severe weather, that not every single location will see damaging thunderstorms. Also, the magnitude of the severe weather threat and tornado potential may vary each day. Check back for updates.</p><p><strong>Wednesday</strong></p><ul><li>The primary corridor for severe thunderstorm potential will exist from the northern Plains and Upper Midwest into parts of southwest Texas.</li><li><strong>Threats:</strong> Damaging wind gusts, large hail and possible isolated tornadoes.</li><li><strong>Cities: <a href=\"/weather/today/l/USMN0503:1:US\">Mpls./St. Paul</a> | <a href=\"/weather/today/l/USNE0363:1:US\">Omaha</a> | <a href=\"/weather/today/l/USTX1464:1:US\">Wichita Falls</a></strong></li></ul><p><div id=\"wxn4\" /></p><p><strong>Thursday</strong></p><ul><li>Severe thunderstorms may be more numerous in the Plains states. This includes parts of Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, eastern Colorado, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas.</li><li><strong>Threats: </strong>Tornadoes, large hail, damaging wind gusts.</li><li><strong>Cities:</strong> <strong><a href=\"/weather/5day/l/USTX0327:1:US\">Dallas</a> |</strong> <strong><a href=\"/weather/today/l/USMO0460:1:US\">Kansas City</a> | </strong><strong><a href=\"/weather/5day/l/USOK0400:1:US\">Okla. City</a> | </strong><strong><a href=\"/weather/5day/l/USKS0620:1:US\">Wichita</a></strong></li></ul><p><div id=\"wxn5\" /></p><p><strong>Friday</strong></p><ul><li>The risk for severe thunderstorms slides slightly east. This includes areas from the Missouri Valley (parts of Iowa and Nebraska to central and east Texas).</li><li><strong>Threats: </strong>Damaging wind gusts, large hail and possible isolated tornadoes.</li><li><strong>Cities: <a href=\"/weather/today/l/USTX0327:1:US\">Dallas</a> | <a href=\"/weather/today/l/USTX0617:1:US\">Houston</a> | <a href=\"/weather/today/l/USLA0426:1:US\">Shreveport</a></strong></li></ul><p><div id=\"wxn6\" /></p><h3>Storm Reports Since Saturday</h3><p><strong>Tuesday: </strong></p><p>Earlier Tuesday afternoon, there was a hailstorm in and around Denver, where the National Weather Service reported hailstones as large as golf balls. In fact, southeast of the city, hail was reported to be completely covering the ground Ã¢ÂÂ in some places so deep that it was considered \"plowable.\"</p><p>There were even a pair of confimed tornadoes in Michigan's Upper Peninsula Tuesday, southwest of Marquette, Michigan. These were the first May tornadoes in Marquette County since at least 1973.</p><p>It wasn't just tornadoes Tuesday. Over six inches of rain triggered severe flash flooding in northeast Arkansas, including the city of Jonesboro. </p><p> </p><p><div id=\"wxn7\" /></p><p><strong>Monday:</strong></p><p>On Monday evening, tornadoes were reported in Oklahoma and Texas. A tornado was spotted on the ground just north of Woodward, Oklahoma. No damage was reported in the area. Another tornado was later reported near Northfield, Texas.</p><p><div id=\"wxn8\" /></p><p>There were a few baseball-size hail reports near Sanderson, Texas, Monday evening. In Silverton, Texas, there was a minor accumulation of 0.75-inch to 1-inch hailstones. Hail the size of golf balls fell west of McLean, Texas.</p><p>Additionally on Monday evening, quarter-size hail covered a portion of I-40 near Lake McClellan, Texas, and 60 mph wind gusts from the same severe thunderstorm overturned a semi-truck along I-40 in the same area. Injures were reported with the overturned semi-truck.</p><p><strong>Sunday:</strong></p><p>There were multiple reports of tornadoes Sunday evening across Texas, Kansas and South Dakota.</p><p>A tornado touched down near Howardwick, Texas, and another tornado was spotted south of Interstate 20 near Big Springs, Texas. A large tornado near Waka, Texas, knocked down a quarter-mile row of power lines. In Kansas, a half-mile wide wedge tornado was reported near Lydia. No major damage has been reported in all of the areas mentioned above.</p><p><div id=\"wxn9\" /></p><p>Hail the size of tennis balls (2.50 inches) led to broken car windows near Post, Texas, Sunday evening, and hail as large as teacups (3 inches) was spotted near Elbow, Texas. Farther north in Nebraska, hail coated the ground near Mullen, where severe thunderstorms left residents without power.</p><p><strong>Saturday:</strong></p><p>Severe weather began late Saturday, but it was confined to parts of eastern Montana, western Kansas and western Texas. There was at least one tornado in Wichita County, Kansas, Saturday evening but no damage was reported.</p><h3>Setup For Severe Weather</h3><p><div id=\"wxn10\" /></p><p>Severe weather is common in the spring when a southward dip in the jet stream (upper trough) pushes eastward from the Rockies to the Plains states. </p><p>That weather pattern is on display through the week ahead.</p><p>A trough of low pressure aloft across the western U.S. will move very slowly eastward this week. As disturbances swing around the base of the trough and eject eastward from the Rocky Mountains to the Plains, a surge of deep moisture will ride northward from the warm Gulf of Mexico.</p><p>Meanwhile, winds aloft (low level jet) coming out of the south will be increasing in intensity. This combination is an ideal recipe for severe thunderstorms to develop.  </p><h3><strong>Snapped An Awesome Shot? Share Your Photo!</strong></h3><p>If you crave pictures of severe weather, you've found your home here. <a href=\"https://profile.weather.com/#/login?returnurl=http:%2F%2Fwww.weather.com%2Fphotos%2Fcollection%2Fugc%2Fweather%2Fstorms%3Fsuw%3Dweb&src=ugc\">Upload your photos or video</a> (taking care to only take photos and videos from a safe location) to us and share your experience!</p><p><strong>(PHOTO/VIDEO GALLERIES: <a href=\"/photos/collection/ugc/news/weather-severe\">Severe</a> | <a href=\"/photos/collection/ugc/weather/storms\">Storms</a>)</strong></p><p><strong>MORE ON WEATHER.COM: Plains Severe Weather - May 9, 2016 (Photo Gallery)</strong></p><h3><div id=\"wxn11\" /></h3>" , "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=320&h=180&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "9" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=485&h=273&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "10" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=650&h=356&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "11" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=815&h=458&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "12" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=ap&w=980&h=551&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "13" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=0&h=366&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "14" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=ap&w=220&h=0&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "15" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=532&h=532&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "16" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=1280&h=720&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "200" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=200&h=200&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "400" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/nader_1.jpg?v=at&w=400&h=400&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0"} , "body" : "<p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>Authorities say one person drowned when a vehicle was swept off a road in central Oklahoma, and two people were critically injured after a tornado touched down near Dodge City, Kansas, as severe storms pummeled parts of the Plains Tuesday afternoon and evening. At least 26 tornadoes have been reported from Colorado to Michigan. </p><p>Here is the latest state-by-state breakdown on this round of severe weather. </p><h3><strong>Oklahoma</strong></h3><p>The Oklahoma Highway Patrol says the flooding death happened early Wednesday near the small town of Davenport, which is about 50 miles northeast of Oklahoma City. The highway patrol says the vehicle was swept into a drainage culvert, and one person was pinned in the floodwaters and drowned.Two others in the vehicle escaped serious injury.</p><p>\"The Davenport area received between 4 and 5 inches of rain over the last 24 hours,\" said weather.com meteorologist Chris Dolce. \"The area could see more heavy bouts of rain through the end of the week.\"</p><p>Possible tornadoes left damage in the towns of Shamrock and Bristow Tuesday evening. The NWS in Tulsa said multiple homes suffered extensive damage near Shamrock, and the Bristow Police Department <a href=\"http://www.newson6.com/story/32056281/damage-injuries-confirmed-after-storm-blows-through-bristow?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter\" target=\"_blank\">confirmed injuries in the area</a>, KOTV reported. In Bristow, the NWS said trees blocked a turnpike entrance ramp, and one home was damaged.</p><p>Both towns are located southwest of Tulsa.</p><p><div id=\"wxn1\" /></p><h3><strong>Kansas</strong></h3><p>The Dodge City tornado was spotted by storm chasers just after 6 p.m. local time Tuesday evening. The National Weather Service confirmed a home was destroyed in Ensign as the tornado moved north toward Dodge City.</p><p>Ã¢ÂÂI started seeing some rotation, and with that rotation, <a href=\"http://ksn.com/2016/05/24/tornadoes-touch-down-in-western-kansas/\" target=\"_blank\">a tornado formed and touched down </a>and started and stayed down,Ã¢ÂÂ Dodge City resident Logan Davis told KSN News.</p><p>Emergency management officials in Ford County reported that two people were critically injured Tuesday night and taken to a hospital in Dodge City, the office said in a statement early Wednesday.</p><p>At about 6:30 p.m., a tornado emergency was declared for the Dodge City area. After the tornado passed, damage was reported on the west side of the city, as well as a propane leak.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/storms/severe/news/severe-weather-forecast-plains-late-may\">Multi-Day Severe Weather Threat Ahead</a>)</strong></p><p><div id=\"wxn2\" /></p><p>Late Tuesday afternoon, a large tornado was reported near Scott City in western Kansas. Captured by chasers and locals alike, the twister was not believed to be responsible for any major damage.</p><p><div id=\"wxn3\" /></p><p>As the severe storms moved eastward late Tuesday evening, flash flooding and straight-line wind gusts caused problems in central Kansas.</p><p>Gusts of 55-60 mph damaged roofs and knocked down power lines in Hoisington, Kansas. Torrential downpours caused major flash flooding in and around Great Bend, Kansas, with 6-12 inches of water reported on several roads, partially due to downed tree limbs backing up the sewage system.</p><p>\"The most dangerous areas tonight appear to be along the dryline, particularly western and south-central Kansas into western Oklahoma (right along the Kansas/Oklahoma border),\" said weather.com meteorologist <a href=\"https://twitter.com/WxBrianD\" target=\"_blank\">Brian Donegan</a>. \"Conditions are conducive for tornado development, and some of the tornadoes could be as strong as EF2. Cities in this area include Dodge City, Kansas, and Woodward, Oklahoma.\"</p><p>Here are the latest impacts from other states affected by this round of severe weather.</p><h3>Michigan</h3><p>Twin tornadoes touched down near Republic, in Marquette County, one to the northeast and one to the northwest.</p><p>The National Weather Service says the first tornado was detected around 2:30 p.m., snapping pine trees more than 12 inches in diameter. The weather service says a second tornado was detected about 3 p.m. near Greenwood Reservoir, damaging trees.</p><p>The twin tornadoes are a rare event for the region. According to weather.com senior meteorologist Jonathan Erdman, the pair are the first May tornadoes in Marquette County since 1973 per NCEI Storm Events. </p><p><span class=\"tL8wMe EMoHub\" dir=\"ltr\" id=\":140.co\">\"Less than two weeks ago, Marquette, Michigan, was blanketed by about an inch of snow,\" Erdman said. \"In addition to the twin Upper Peninsula tornadoes, Alpena, Michigan, set a record high of 89 degrees Tuesday.\"</span></p><p><div id=\"wxn4\" /></p><h3><strong>Arkansas</strong></h3><p>Authorities told KAIT-TV that a 13-year-old boy who was reported missing in Jonesboro, Arkansas, <a href=\"http://www.kait8.com/story/32055320/teen-lost-in-flood-water-found-alive?sf26885029=1\" target=\"_blank\">has been found alive</a> after he was swept away by high water. Witnesses said they saw the boy get sucked into a drainage pipe as flooding swamped parts of the city, the report added.</p><p>Jonesboro police say the boy fell into the storm drain Tuesday after storms dumped more than 4 inches of rain on the area, about 130 miles northeast of Little Rock. Two officers searching the area pulled the boy to safety after hearing his cries for help.</p><p>Police Cpl. Jason Chester tells television station KAIT that the boy said he clung to a pole until the officers rescued him about three hours after his ordeal began.</p><p>A flash flood emergency was declared for Jonesboro Tuesday evening because of extremely heavy rainfall, according to the NWS's Memphis office.</p><p><div id=\"wxn5\" /></p><p><div id=\"wxn6\" /></p><h3><strong>Colorado</strong></h3><p>Earlier in the afternoon, a hailstorm occurred Tuesday in and around Denver, where the NWS reported hailstones as large as 1.5 inches in diameter.</p><p>Southeast of Denver, NWS storm reports noted that the hail had piled up so deep during the storm that it was \"plowable,\" meaning snow plows were needed to clear roadways.</p><p>Here's how the Denver hailstorm looked on social media:</p><p><div id=\"wxn7\" /></p><p><div id=\"wxn8\" /></p><p><div id=\"wxn9\" /></p><p><div id=\"wxn10\" /></p>" , "flags" : { "Facebook" : true , "Intranet" : false , "TV App" : false , "Twitter" : true , "YouTube" : true , "Google+" : true , "Big Web" : true , "Little Web" : true , "Mobile Apps" : true , "orig_source" : "Reboot"} , "wxnodes" : [ { "id" : "wxn0" , "schema_version" : "1.1.12" , "type" : "wxnode_video" , "align" : "" , "options" : [ "show_descriptions"] , "assetid" : "" , "clipid" : "" , "collection" : "9a45de46-ae7b-4ca3-8bc7-eaa8669078ae" , "collection_name" : "pl-severe-tornado-impact-stories" , "playlist_type" : "playlist"} , { "id" : "wxn1" , "type" : "wxnode_content_well" , "contentwell" : "<center><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-partner=\"tweetdeck\"><p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">Damage to several homes nw of Bristow near hwy 16. "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/map_specnewsdct-54_ltst_4namus_enus_650x366_0.jpg?v=at&w=1280&h=720&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "200" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/map_specnewsdct-54_ltst_4namus_enus_650x366_0.jpg?v=at&w=200&h=200&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "400" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/map_specnewsdct-54_ltst_4namus_enus_650x366_0.jpg?v=at&w=400&h=400&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0"} , "body" : "<p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>The weekend of Memorial Day 2016 could be filled with stormy weather for parts of the Midwest and East, but warmer temperatures are expected to finally arrive in those regions just in time for the holiday.</p><p>In the West, however, temperatures will be a bit below average with some showers in the forecast.</p><p>AAA expects the volume of automotive travel this Memorial Day weekend to be the <a href=\"http://newsroom.aaa.com/tag/memorial-day-travel-forecast/\">second-heaviest on record with 38 million travelers</a>.</p><p>With that in mind, here's what travelers can expect this weekend.</p><h3><strong>Friday</strong></h3><h3><div id=\"wxn1\" /></h3><p><b>Overview</b></p><ul><li><b>Wet Areas: </b>The central portion of the country has the greatest chance of showers and thunderstorms. Pop-up thunderstorms of the hit-or-miss variety are expected in the East and Northeast, but many places will escape the day rain-free.</li><li><strong>Dry Areas: </strong>California eastward into the Desert Southwest will enjoy dry weather. Many areas of the deep south will remain mostly rain free.</li><li><b>High Temperatures: </b>Highs mainly in the 80s are expected across the eastern one-third of the country and across the south. The main exceptions will be coastal areas, due to afternoon sea breezes, and northern New England, where temperatures hold in the 60s and 70s. The West, the Rockies, and northern Plains will have highs in the 60s and 70s, while the Desert Southwest rises into the 90s.</li></ul><p><strong>Major highways impacted:</strong></p><ul><li>Interstate 35 from Kansas City to Oklahoma City (showers and thunderstorms)</li><li>I-30 from Dallas to Little Rock, Arkansas (showers and thunderstorms)</li><li>I-94 from Minneapolis to Chicago (showers and thunderstorms)</li></ul><h3><strong>Saturday</strong></h3><h3><div id=\"wxn2\" /></h3><p><b>Overview</b></p><ul><li><b>Wet Areas: </b>The Upper Midwest has the greatest chance of showers and thunderstorms. Pop-up thunderstorms of the hit-or-miss variety are expected in the Northeast as well as in the Mississippi Valley, but many of these places will stay dry. Showers and thunderstorms may be possible along the east coast from Miami, Florida to southern Virginia. We'll have to watch the Southeast coast ahead of increasing moisture due to a possible subtropical or tropical low pressure area. </li><li><strong>Dry Areas: </strong>California eastward into the Rockies and Desert Southwest will enjoy a dry day. Much of the mid-Atlantic and interior Southeast will also be dry.</li><li><b>High Temperatures: </b>Highs mainly in the 80s are expected across the eastern two-thirds of the country. The main exceptions will be coastal areas, due to afternoon sea breezes, where temperatures hold in the 70s. A isolated areas in Florida and Texas will see 90s. The West, northern Plains and the Rockies will again have highs in the 60s and 70s, while the Desert Southwest rises into the 90s.</li></ul><p><strong>Major highways impacted:</strong></p><ul><li>Interstate 94 from Minneapolis to the Chicago (showers and thunderstorms)</li><li>I-70 from Indianapolis to Wheeling, West Virginia (showers and thunderstorms)</li><li>I-90 from Billings, Montana, to Madison, Wisconsin (showers and thunderstorms)</li></ul><h3><strong>Sunday</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn3\" /></p><p><b>Overview</b></p><ul><li><b>Wet Areas: </b>The Plains states and upper Midwest have the greatest chance of showers and thunderstorms. Pop-up thunderstorms of the hit-or-miss variety are expected in the Northeast once again, but a lot of places will remain dry. Additionally, we'll have to watch the Southeast coast and Carolinas closely for possible <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/atlantic-basin-tropical-subtropical-development-late-may-early-june-2016\">subtropical or tropical development</a>. Increasing showers and storms are likely from the Mid-Atlantic into Florida. </li><li><strong>Dry Areas: </strong>California eastward into the Desert Southwest will enjoy a dry day. The Pacific Northwest through the Northern Plains will also be mostly dry.</li><li><b>High Temperatures: </b>Highs mainly in the 80s are expected across the eastern two-thirds of the country. The main exceptions will be coastal areas, due to afternoon sea breezes, and New England, where temperatures will again hold in the 70s. The West and the Rockies will have highs in the 60s and 70s, while the Desert Southwest rises well into the 90s.</li></ul><p><strong>Major highways impacted:</strong></p><ul><li>Interstate 95 from Richmond to Melbourne, Florida showers and thunderstorms)</li><li>I-35 from Kansas City, Missouri to Laredo, Texas (showers and thunderstorms)</li><li>I-40 from Little Rock, Arkansas, to Oklahoma City (showers and thunderstorms)</li></ul><h3><strong>Memorial Day</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn4\" /></p><p><b>Overview</b></p><ul><li><b>Wet Areas: </b>The Plains states, and Ohio Valley once again has the greatest chance of showers and thunderstorms. Pop-up thunderstorms of the hit-or-miss variety are possible in the Northeast, but a lot of places will escape the holiday rain-free. In addition, we'll have to continue watching the Southeast coast up through the mid-Atlantic coast closely for possible <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/atlantic-basin-tropical-subtropical-development-late-may-early-june-2016\">subtropical or tropical development</a>.</li><li><strong>Dry Areas: </strong>The majority of the West eastward into the Rockies will enjoy a dry day. Much of the Gulf Coast will also be dry.</li><li><b>High Temperatures: </b>Highs mainly in the 80s are expected across the eastern two-thirds of the country.  The main exceptions will be coastal areas, due to afternoon sea breezes, and New England, where temperatures will hold in the 70s again. Portions of the deep south will rise into the low 90s. The West and the Rockies will have highs mainly in the 70s, while the Desert Southwest again rises well into the 90s.</li></ul><p><strong>Major highways impacted:</strong></p><ul><li>Potentially Interstate 95 from Jacksonville to Richmond (watching for possible <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/atlantic-basin-tropical-subtropical-development-late-may-early-june-2016\">subtropical or tropical development</a>)</li><li>I-35 from Dallas to Kansas City (showers and thunderstorms)</li><li>I-80 from Cheyenne, Wyoming, to Des Moines, Iowa (showers and thunderstorms)</li></ul><p><strong>MORE ON WEATHER.COM: Vintage Memorial Day</strong></p><p><div id=\"wxn5\" "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/enso-23may2016-sst-anoms.jpg?v=at&w=815&h=458&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "12" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/enso-23may2016-sst-anoms.jpg?v=ap&w=980&h=551&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "13" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/enso-23may2016-sst-anoms.jpg?v=at&w=0&h=366&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "14" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/enso-23may2016-sst-anoms.jpg?v=ap&w=220&h=0&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "15" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/enso-23may2016-sst-anoms.jpg?v=at&w=532&h=532&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "16" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/enso-23may2016-sst-anoms.jpg?v=at&w=1280&h=720&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "200" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/enso-23may2016-sst-anoms.jpg?v=at&w=200&h=200&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "400" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/enso-23may2016-sst-anoms.jpg?v=at&w=400&h=400&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0"} , "body" : "<p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>The El NiÃÂ±o of 2015-16 may have finally dissipated, according to just-released data from NOAA.</p><p><a href=\"http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/data/indices/wksst8110.for\" target=\"_blank\">Sea-surface temperature anomalies</a> in the so-called NiÃÂ±o 3.4 region of the central and eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean dipped below the +0.5 degree Celsius El NiÃÂ±o threshold the week of May 15-21, after three-month running mean anomalies <a href=\"/news/climate/news/el-nino-ties-record-january-2016\">tied the record for the strongest El NiÃÂ±o</a> this past winter.</p><p>El NiÃÂ±o, the periodic warming of the equatorial eastern and central Pacific Ocean, can shift weather patterns over a period of months, bringing the possibility of more sustained warm, cold, wet or dry weather in parts of the world.</p><p><div id=\"wxn1\" /></p><p>The rapid weakening of this strong El NiÃÂ±o this late winter and spring was quite dramatic, with positive surface anomalies virtually vanishing in about 3.5 months' time since the week of Groundhog Day, according to NOAA's Climate Prediction Center. </p><p>The May 15-21 weekly anomaly of only +0.2ÃÂC was the lowest positive anomaly in the NiÃÂ±o 3.4 region since the week of Aug. 13, 2014.</p><p><div id=\"wxn2\" /></p><p><a href=\"http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/enso/?cid=009tw04#tabs=Overview\" target=\"_blank\">Australia's Bureau of Meteorology</a> declared El NiÃÂ±o finished on May 24, citing both cooling sea-surface temperatures, as well as atmospheric indicators such as stronger trade winds (the easterly winds near the equator) and diminished cloudiness (showers) near the International Date Line over the past few months.</p><p>In an eye-catching NOAA animation released in mid-May, you could see the colder-than-average water swarming eastward across the International Date Line, eating away at the warmer-than-average equatorial Pacific water from below.</p><p><div id=\"wxn3\" /></p><p>For bookkeeping purposes, NOAA typically uses the three-month running mean anomalies to define the beginning and end of El NiÃÂ±o and its opposite, La NiÃÂ±a. Think of this as somewhat similar to how economists wait to define a recession until sometime after it actually began or ended.</p><p>NOAA declared the El NiÃÂ±o had begun during the Feb.-April 2015 period.</p><p>El NiÃÂ±o and La NiÃÂ±a events typically only last for nine to 12 months, and typically recur again every two to seven years, according to Columbia University's International Research Institute for Climate and Society.</p><p>(<b>MORE: </b><a href=\"/news/climate/news/compare-el-nino-1997-98-2015-16\" style=\"font-weight: bold;\">A Tale of Two El NiÃÂ±os ...</a><strong><a href=\"/news/climate/news/compare-el-nino-1997-98-2015-16\"> What Made This One Different?</a></strong>)</p><p>At any rate, these trends suggest La NiÃÂ±a, the periodic cooling of equatorial Pacific Ocean water, is increasingly likely by late summer or fall, consistent with the large majority of model forecasts. A couple of ensemble forecasts even have a strong La NiÃÂ±a forecasted by late summer or fall.</p><p><div id=\"wxn4\" /></p><p>Both NOAA's Climate Prediction Center and Australia's Bureau of Meteorology issued a \"La NiÃÂ±a watch,\" indicating La NiÃÂ±a may develop within the next six months. NOAA/CPC places the odds of La NiÃÂ±a conditions by late summer at over 60 percent, increasing to over a 75 percent likelihood by late fall.</p><p>Flip-flops from a strong El NiÃÂ±o to La NiÃÂ±a are not unusual. Following the record strong El NiÃÂ±o of 1997-98, La NiÃÂ±a almost immediately set in the following summer, reaching moderate-to-strong intensity before finally ending in spring 2001.</p><p>A similar situation occurred following the strong El NiÃÂ±o of 1972-73. However, neutral conditions followed three other strong El NiÃÂ±os of 1982-83, 1965-66 and 1957-58.</p><h3><strong>What Does It Mean for Your Forecast?</strong></h3><h3>Summer 2016</h3><p>There are some broad trends that have shown up in past weakening El NiÃÂ±o events that could give a hint on what to expect this summer.</p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/forecast/national/news/june-summer-temperature-forecast\">Summer Outlook 2016</a></strong>)</p><p>\"If we look at rapidly decaying historical ENSO events (trends, instead of actual values), we see that the summer heat is centered in the northern Plains into the Great Lakes states,\" said <a href=\"https://twitter.com/tcrawf_nh\" target=\"_blank\">Dr. Todd Crawford</a>, chief meteorologist at The Weather Company's energy division.</p><h3><div id=\"wxn5\" /></h3><h3>Atlantic Hurricane Season 2016</h3><p><a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-season-2016-after-strong-el-nino\">Strengthening El NiÃÂ±os during the Atlantic hurricane season tend to yield stronger wind shear</a>, which tends to tear apart developing or mature tropical cyclones.</p><p>Sure enough, June through Oct. 2015 Caribbean wind shear was the highest on record dating to 1979, according to <a href=\"https://twitter.com/philklotzbach\" target=\"_blank\">Dr. Phil Klotzbach</a>, tropical scientist at Colorado State University.</p><p><div id=\"wxn6\" /></p><p>Klotzbach also found that the chance of a U.S. hurricane impact rises dramatically in a La NiÃÂ±a or neutral (neither El NiÃÂ±o or La NiÃÂ±a) season compared to an El NiÃÂ±o season.</p><p><div id=\"wxn7\" /></p><p>This at least loads the dice a bit toward an increased chance of tropical cyclones surviving into the Caribbean Sea, or forming there, particularly later in the season as El NiÃÂ±o disappears farther in the rear-view mirror.</p><p>If El NiÃÂ±o was the only factor, that is.</p><p>The odds may shift a bit toward a more active Atlantic hurricane season in 2016, but El NiÃÂ±o's absence doesn't guarantee that outcome.</p><p><a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-season-2016-after-strong-el-nino\">As we wrote in Jan. 2016</a>, prior hurricane seasons after strong El NiÃÂ±os have produced anywhere from only four named storms (1983) to 14 named storms (1998), three hurricanes (1983) to 10 hurricanes (1998). </p><p>This fizzled El NiÃÂ±o also doesn't mean the season poses any greater threat to the U.S. compared to any other year, as landfalls tend to be poorly correlated with numbers of named storms.</p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/2016-hurricane-season-forecast-atlantic-colorado-state-csu\">2016 Atlantic Hurricane Season Outlook</a></strong>)</p><h3>Winter 2016-17</h3><p>We've said many times an El NiÃÂ±o, La NiÃÂ±a, or the lack of either, known as the neutral phase, is only one large-scale forcing on the atmosphere. It is not the be-all and end-all determining whether a season is wet, dry, cold or warm.</p><p>Despite that, the peak atmospheric response to the equatorial Pacific anomalies tends to occur in the northern hemisphere winter months. </p><p>So, in the event we have a La NiÃÂ±a settling in by fall or winter, let's take a look at December-February U.S. temperature and precipitation anomalies during weak (SST anomalies from 0.5 to 0.9 degrees below average), moderate (1.0 to 1.4 degrees below average) and strong (1.5 degrees below average or cooler) La NiÃÂ±as.</p><p><strong>Temperatures</strong></p><p>While there are some differences among La NiÃÂ±a magnitudes, some commonalities emerge regarding La NiÃÂ±a winter forcing in the U.S.:</p><ul><li><strong>Cold: </strong>Northern Plains, Upper Midwest, New England, New York state, West Coast</li><li><strong>Warm: </strong>Southern Plains, Southeast</li></ul><p>Neglecting other factors, it appears the stronger the La NiÃÂ±a, the stronger the likelihood the winter warmth spreads farther north into the Corn Belt, Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic states.</p><p><div id=\"wxn8\" /></p><p><strong>Precipitation</strong></p><p>Again, despite some differences among La NiÃÂ±a magnitudes, some commonalities are apparent:</p><ul><li><strong>Wet: </strong>Pacific Northwest, Bitterroots (western Montana/Idaho), parts of the Ohio Valley, Tennessee Valley</li><li><strong>Dry: </strong>Southern Plains, Gulf/Southeast coast including Florida, Southern California, Desert Southwest</li></ul><p><div id=\"wxn9\" /></p><p><strong>MORE ON WEATHER.COM: NASA Climate Change Satellite Images</strong></p><p><div id=\"wxn10\" /></p>" , "flags" : { "Facebook" : true , "Intranet" reference=\"News/first-snowfall-map.txt\" resources=\"News/first-snowfall-map.txt\"></wxnode:module></p><p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>As we move through the spring, days generally become warmer and more comfortable, but we all know that the hot days will be coming, if they haven't already.</p><p>There's something about the 90-degree threshold that seems to be the demarcation line for what we perceive as hot, so we researched National Weather Service 30-year average data to find the date by which the season's first 90-degree day occurs.</p><p>Keep in mind, these are averages that include early and late 90-degree events over a 30-year period. They can vary from year to year depending on the general weather pattern.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/atlantic-basin-tropical-subtropical-development-late-may-early-june-2016\">NHC Monitoring Possible Tropical or Subtropical Development Off the Coast</a>)</strong></p><p>The tables below list average date when you can expect the first 90-degree high temperature and how many 90-degree days, or higher, that you can expect on average in any given year.</p><p>For most locations across the Southwest and Deep South, the average first 90-degree day ranges from April to mid-May.</p><h3><strong>Northeast</strong></h3><p>Late May through June is when we can generally expect the mercury to reach 90 degrees for the first time. This date is usually quite a bit later in the higher elevations.</p><p>Temperatures can sometimes reach 90 degrees more easily with west or southwest \"downsloping\" winds on the east side of the Appalachians toward the East Coast.</p><p>Cities farther north and along the shores of the Great Lakes will see much fewer 90-degree days.</p><table align=\"center\" border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" style=\"width: 500px;\"><tbody><tr><td>City</td><td>Avg. First 90-Degree Day</td><td>Avg. Number of 90-Degree Days </td></tr><tr><td>Philadelphia</td><td>             May 24</td><td>                     27</td></tr><tr><td>New York</td><td>             May 27</td><td>                     17</td></tr><tr><td>Boston</td><td>             May 31</td><td>                     13</td></tr><tr><td>Burlington</td><td>             Jun.  12</td><td>                       7</td></tr><tr><td>Buffalo</td><td>             Jun.  20</td><td>                       3</td></tr></tbody></table><h3><strong>Midwest</strong></h3><p>Many cities in this region are likely to see their first 90-degree day in June. The cooling effects of the Great Lakes can moderate the immediate area around them and delay the onset of 90-degree high temperatures.</p><p>Cities farther south will see far more 90-degree days per season.</p><table align=\"center\" border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" style=\"width: 500px;\"><tbody><tr><td>City</td><td>Avg. First 90-Degree Day</td><td>Avg. Number Of 90-Degree Days</td></tr><tr><td>Minneapolis</td><td>              Jun. 1</td><td>                     14</td></tr><tr><td>Chicago</td><td>              Jun. 8</td><td>                     17</td></tr><tr><td>Detroit</td><td>              Jun. 12 </td><td>                     12</td></tr><tr><td>Cincinnati</td><td>              Jun. 9</td><td>                     77</td></tr><tr><td>Kansas City</td><td>             May 26</td><td>                     47</td></tr></tbody></table><h3><strong>West</strong></h3><p>Unless you are in the mountains, most of the Southwest experiences their first high of 90 degrees in April or early May. Cities located on the Pacific Coast or in the Rockies will have few 90-degree days.</p><table align=\"center\" border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" style=\"width: 500px;\"><tbody><tr><td>City</td><td>Avg. First 90-Degree Day</td><td>Avg. Number Of 90-Degree Days</td></tr><tr><td>Seattle</td><td>             Jul.  3</td><td>                       3</td></tr><tr><td>Portland</td><td>             Jun. 15</td><td>                      14</td></tr><tr><td>San Francisco</td><td>             Jun. 10</td><td>                        4</td></tr><tr><td>Salt Lake City</td><td>             Jun.  3</td><td>                      57</td></tr><tr><td>Denver</td><td>             Jun.  2</td><td>                      37</td></tr></tbody></table><h3><strong>South</strong></h3><p>The average first 90-degree day has already passed for most locations in the Deep South. Cities farther north or at higher elevations will see their first 90-degree day later, and will see fewer of them.</p><table align=\"center\" border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" style=\"width: 500px;\"><tbody><tr><td>City</td><td>Avg. First 90-Degree Day</td><td>Avg. Number Of 90-Degree Days</td></tr><tr><td>Louisville</td><td>            Jun.  5</td><td>                       38</td></tr><tr><td>Greensboro</td><td>            May 25</td><td>                       32</td></tr><tr><td>Atlanta</td><td>            Jun.  1</td><td>                       44</td></tr><tr><td>Birmingham</td><td>            May 25</td><td>                       61</td></tr><tr><td>Nashville</td><td>            Jun.  2</td><td>                       48</td></tr></tbody></table><p><br><strong>MORE ON WEATHER.COM: Old-Timey Heatwaves</strong></p><p><div wildfire in western Canada traveled across the Atlantic Ocean and into Europe over the weekend Ã¢ÂÂ a distance of more than 4,000 miles.</p><p>The dangerous wildfire broke out in Fort McMurray, Alberta, on May 1 and continues to burn. At least two deaths were indirectly attributed to the inferno and more than 2,400 homes and businesses have been lost citywide.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"/safety/wildfires/news/fort-mcmurray-wildfire-facts\">Why It's Called the #</a><a href=\"/safety/wildfires/news/fort-mcmurray-wildfire-facts\">YMMfire</a>)</strong></p><p>In the three images below, you can see how satellites sensed the aerosols associated with the smoke as winds aloft transported them from Alberta across the northern Atlantic Ocean May 20-22. The blue, green, yellow, orange and purple shadings illustrate where the aerosols were concentrated each day as they spread eastward.</p><p><div id=\"wxn1\" /></p><p><div id=\"wxn2\" /></p><p>The smoke reached Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom by May 21.</p><p><div id=\"wxn3\" /></p><p>On May 22, it moved farther across Spain into continental Europe. In fact, the smoke ended up moving past the U.K. and over northern Europe.</p><p>Smoke from the Fort McMurray wildfire has since retreated back into Canada as firefighters continue battling this large blaze.</p><p><div id=\"wxn4\" /><div id=\"wxn5\" /></p><p><strong>MORE ON WEATHER.COM: Aerials of Alberta Wildfire</strong></p><p><div id=\"wxn6\" /></p>" , "flags" : { "Facebook" : true , "Intranet"
