"https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=at&w=485&h=273&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "10" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=at&w=650&h=356&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "11" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=at&w=815&h=458&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "12" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=ap&w=980&h=551&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "13" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=at&w=0&h=366&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "14" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=ap&w=220&h=0&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "15" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=at&w=532&h=532&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "16" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=at&w=1280&h=720&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "200" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=at&w=200&h=200&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "400" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/cordova-shidner-snow-bedroom_980x551.jpg?v=at&w=400&h=400&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0"} , "body" : "<p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>Some weather events are so strange they capture the fascination of even the most grizzled meteorologists.</p><p>A thunderstorm with quarter-size hail, a menacing <a href=\"/storms/severe/news/strong-storms-shelf-clouds\">shelf cloud</a>, or even a full-fledged blizzard are certainly impressive.</p><p>But some storms are exceptional in magnitude, extremely rare for a given area or time of year, or, just flat out bizarre.</p><p>While a full history of the strangest weather is beyond the scope of this piece, I thought I'd take a look at some of the most bizarre things in weather I've seen in my lifetime, dating to the early 1970s. </p><p>I'd love to rank these, but they're all so bizarre in their own way. So enjoy this look at weather's weird side.</p><h3><strong>Two Large Tornadoes at Once</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn1\" /></p><p>The sight of one large tornado is frightening enough, let alone two side-by-side.</p><p>A supercell thundestorm near Pilger, Nebraska, on June 16, 2014, surprised both residents and even veteran storm chasers.</p><p>(<strong>IN-DEPTH: <a href=\"/storms/tornado/news/pilger-nebraska-twin-tornadoes-how-they-happened-20140617\">Science Behind the Pilger Twin Tornadoes</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>A Snowy Break-In</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn2\" /></p><p>After over a month's worth of heavy snowstorms, a \"mini-avalanche\" of snow broke through an Alaska home in January 2012. </p><p>\"I didn't realize that it had also come in through our bedroom,\" said Cynthia Shidner of Valdez, Alaska, after the snow barged in. </p><p>\"And my husband was actually in bed with snow on him.\" Four Coast Guard volunteers helped the Shidner family shovel out their home.</p><p>A state of emergency was declared and National Guard troops were called out to help clear out homes and roads in nearby Cordova, where drifts 12-14 feet high were reported.<br> </p><h3><strong>Hurricane Season \"Goes Greek\"</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn3\" /></p><p>One of the few light moments in the otherwise terrible, <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/2005-hurricane-season-by-the-numbers\">historic 2005 Atlantic hurricane season</a> was prompted by the Greek alphabet.</p><p>For the first time, all 21 names provided by the World Meteorological Organization for the 2005 Atlantic season had been used once record-setting <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/florida-hurricane-drought-10-years-2015\">Hurricane Wilma</a> came into play.</p><p>Therefore, on Oct. 22, as Wilma was lashing Cancun, National Hurricane Center (NHC) meteorologists upgraded a new storm southeast of HispaÃÂ±ola to Tropical Storm Alpha. Yes, Alpha, the first letter of the Greek alphabet.</p><p>If that wasn't enough, another five named storms formed, ending with Tropical Storm Zeta, which lagged into the new year.</p><p>Alpha's mudslides did claim 26 lives in HispaÃÂ±ola, and 400 homes were damaged or destroyed in Haiti, according to the NHC.<br> </p><h3><strong>A North Pole Thaw ... in December</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn4\" /></p><p>A powerful storm that hit Iceland in late December 2015 helped pull mild air, byArctic standards, all the way to the North Pole.</p><p>On Dec. 30, a buoy located near the North Pole reported a temperature of 33.2 degrees Fahrenheit (0.7 degrees Celsius). This makes it plausible that the North Pole itself may have briefly reached or exceeded the freezing mark (32 degrees), <a href=\"http://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/\" target=\"_blank\">according to the National Snow and Ice Data Center</a>.</p><p>Temperatures this mild are about 50 degrees Fahrenheit above average for late December at the North Pole. In addition, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/bhensonweather/status/681684131411931138\" target=\"_blank\">only three other times since 1948 has the North Pole seen temperatures at or above the freezing mark in December</a>, according to reanalysis data.<br> </p><h3><strong>Windiest NFL Game</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn5\" /></p><p>Green Bay's Ice Bowl (1967) and Cincinnati's Freezer Bowl (1982) are two of the National Football League's most famous bad-weather games. In my opinion, however, a more recent game was more meteorologically bizarre.</p><p>On Dec. 28, 2008, the NFL's New England Patriots and Buffalo Bills played through a game in which the winds were so strong the goalposts had to be straightened four different times, three of those before kickoff.</p><p>Gusts to 75 mph damaged the Bills' practice fieldhouse prior to kickoff.</p><p>Patriots kicker Stephen Gostkowski actually hit 2 of 3 field goal attempts. Bills kicker Rian Lindell missed his only kick, initially going left, but then veering sharply right of the goalposts.<br> </p><h3><strong>Hail Glaciers</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn6\" /><br>On April 11, 2012, a single supercell thunderstorm dumped torrential rain and hail near Dumas, Texas, north of Amarillo.</p><p>The volume of both hail and rain overwhelmed a shallow gully, or draw, near the U.S. 287 bridge, piling the water and ice mass into massive drifts up to 10 feet high, trapping vehicles and forcing closure of the road for 12 hours.   </p><p>A <a href=\"http://www.srh.noaa.gov/images/ama/research/hail_glaciers.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">study on so-called \"hail glaciers\"</a> from National Weather Service Meteorologists Justyn Jackson, T. Todd Lindley, and Jane Love, from the New Mexico Bureau of Geology and Mineral Resources uncovered two other events in the recent past:</p><ul><li>Aug. 14, 2004 (Clayton, N.M.): Up to 16-foot hail glaciers. Some ice cover lasted almost a month, even in late summer.</li><li>May 9, 1994 (Dalhart, Texas): Up to three-foot hail drifts shutdown U.S. 385 for almost one month.<br> </li></ul><h3><strong>White Christmas in South Texas</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn7\" /></p><p>If you tried to escape winter with a trip to South Padre for Christmas 2004, you rolled snake eyes.</p><p>Arctic air plunging south intercepted a vigorous upper-level disturbance to produce a White Christmas in Deep South Texas.</p><p>It was the first day of measurable snowfall since 1895 in Brownsville, Texas. The same latitude as Miami. On Christmas Day, no less.</p><p>This was the heaviest 24-hour snow on record in nearby Victoria, Texas (12.5 inches) and the snowstorm of record in Corpus Christi (4.4 inches).  <br> </p><h3><strong>Record Strongest Hurricane Makes Landfall, Few Deaths</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn8\" /><br>If the strongest hurricane on record in the western hemisphere was headed for a landfall, you might fear for the lives of hundreds, if not thousands in its path.</p><p>At its peak, <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-patricia-mexico-coast\">Hurricane Patricia packed maximum sustained winds of 215 mph</a> in late October 2015 off the southwest Mexican coast. It's lowest central pressure was later found to bottom out at 872 millibars, only 2 millibars from the global record set by Super Typhoon Tip in 1979.</p><p>Still powerful, Patricia weakened to a <a href=\"/safety/hurricane/news/saffir-simpson-hurricane-wind-scale\">Category 4</a> hurricane before making landfall, but did so in a rather sparsely populated area north of Manzanillo, Mexico.</p><p>\"Had the center jogged only 20-30 miles east, the core would've been over an area with 10 times the population density,\" said <a href=\"https://twitter.com/michaelrlowry\" target=\"_blank\">Michael Lowry</a>, hurricane specialist with The Weather Channel.</p><p>Patricia's small wind field and the steep ocean floor offshore meant it couldn't generate a huge storm surge, according to Lowry.</p><p>Only two deaths were directly attributed to Hurricane Patricia, from a fallen tree on a campsite.<br> </p><h3><strong>7 Tornadoes Hit One Town on One Night</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn9\" /><br>Earlier, we discussed the frightening sight of two large tornadoes at once. </p><p>One Nebraska city more than tripled that in one awful June evening.</p><p>Seven tornadoes were spawned by a single, slow-moving supercell thunderstorm in less than three hours on June 3, 1980, in and near Grand Island, Nebraska. </p><p>Thanks, in part, to the parent supercell's slow movement, the most destructive tornado, rated F4, strangely moved from east of town west into the south side of Grand Island before turning south. </p><p>The other area tornadoes also took erratic, loopy paths over their previous damage paths.</p><p>Five were killed and another 193 were injured, with damage estimated around $300 million. <br> </p><h3><strong>A Spring Snow Survey Without the Snow</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn10\" /></p><p>Each April 1, the California Department of Water Resources conducts a statewide snow survey, including manual measurements of the Sierra snowpack in several locations. Roughly one-third of California's drinking water comes from the Sierra snowpack, which after melting later in the spring and summer replenishes the state's reservoirs.</p><p>There's usually several feet of snow still on the ground in the Sierra at the time of this spring snow survey, requiring a rather long snowpack measuring pole.</p><p>For the first time, the spring 2015 snow survey and news conference near Echo Summit was conducted on bare grass. Cooperative Snow Surveys Program chief Frank Gehrke could only point to the height on a measuring pole that was the previous record low snowpack there.</p><p>Statewide, the snowpack was only 5 percent of the average on April 1, 2015, by far the lowest on record for that date. <br> </p><h3><strong>The Most Unlucky Island in 2015</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn11\" /><br>Tiny <a href=\"/weather/radar/interactive/l/YMXX6935:1:YM?interactiveMapLayer=sat&baseMap=r&zoom=5\">Socotra Island</a> in the Arabian Sea just east of the Horn of Africa may have been the unluckiest place in the world in 2015, meteorologically speaking.</p><p>First, <a href=\"/news/weather/news/cyclone-chapala-socotra-yemen\">Cyclone Chapala's eyewall lashed the island on Nov. 1</a>. Chapala had become the farthest south <a href=\"/safety/hurricane/news/saffir-simpson-hurricane-wind-scale\">Category 4</a> intensity tropical cyclone of record in the Arabian Sea.</p><p><a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/cyclone-chapala-yemen-oman-arabian-peninsula\">Chapala then made an unprecedented hurricane-strength landfall on the Gulf of Aden coast of Yemen</a>, triggering flooding in the city of Al Mukalla and surrounding areas.</p><p>Incredibly one week later, <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/cyclone-megh-five-yemen-socotra-somalia-arabian-peninsula\">Cyclone Megh</a> made a direct hit on Socotra as a <a href=\"/safety/hurricane/news/saffir-simpson-hurricane-wind-scale\">Category 2 or 3 storm</a>, according to the India Meteorological Department. </p><p>While tropical cyclones in the Arabian Sea aren't unusual at all, this appears to have been the first time on record of back-to-back cyclones hitting Socotra in a week's time.</p><p>Contrast that with Florida, which marked <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/florida-hurricane-drought-10-years-2015\">10 years since its last hurricane landfall in 2015</a>.<br> </p><h3><strong>The Perfect Storm's Strange Ending</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn12\" /><br>You've probably seen the movie, and may have read the best-selling book, so you're probably at least somewhat aware of how destructive the \"Perfect Storm\" was along parts of the Eastern Seaboard.</p><p>(<strong>FULL RECAP: <a href=\"http://com/holiday/halloween/news/historic-halloween-storms-20120910#/1\">The Perfect Storm</a></strong>)</p><p>Low pressure off Nova Scotia absorbing Hurricane Grace's energy and moisture was impressive enough. </p><p>As the overall storm began to weaken after lashing the East Coast as far south as North Carolina, a tiny circulation within the storm intensified into a full-fledged hurricane on Nov. 1, 1991.</p><p>This hurricane was never named, for fear of alarming and confusing the public after the hard hit from the Perfect Storm. The so-called \"Unnamed Hurricane\" remained well out to sea, and only limped ashore as a weakening tropical storm in Nova Scotia the next day.<br> </p><h3><strong>Hail in Paradise</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn13\" /></p><p>The hailstone pictured above measured 4.25 inches in length, roughly comparable to the diameter of a softball. Any guesses where? Texas? Oklahoma? Alabama? Good guesses, but they're all roughly 4,000 miles off.</p><p>A supercell thunderstorm dropped numerous 2 to 3 inch diameter hailstones, as well as the huge one above, on the island of Oahu, Hawaii, on March 9, 2012. This shattered the previous state record 1 inch diameter hailstone, roughly the size of a quarter.</p><p>The Western Regional Climate Center's \"Climate of Hawaii\" says thunderstorms are reported somewhere in Hawaii about 20-30 days each year.  It goes on to say thunderstorms there are \"infrequent enough so that many people who have lived only in Hawaii have no real notion of the violence of mainland thunderstorms.\"<br> </p><h3><strong>Buried in Boston</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn14\" /></p><p>In the winter of 2014-15, seasonal snow records were smashed in several New England cities, including Boston.</p><p>Incredibly, a parade of snowstorms delivered much of that snow in just 30 days.</p><p>From Jan. 24-Feb. 22, 2015, Boston picked up 94.4 inches, just under 8 feet of snow, obliterating its previous record 30-day snowfall from the infamous winter of 1978 by almost 3 feet.</p><p>Two of Boston's seven heaviest snowstorms of record occurred within an 11-15 day period.  </p><p>It's no wonder driving down city streets, clearing a driveway, or even just finding some semblance of a sidewalk was a chore, even for typically winter-resilient coastal New England.</p><p>(<strong>FULL RECAP: <a href=\"/news/news/new-england-boston-record-snow-tracker\">New England's Record Snow 2014-2015</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Nadine's \"Scribbling\"</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn15\" /></p><p>The path of Hurricane Nadine in September and early October 2012 resembled a toddler's scribbling instead of a typical hurricane path.</p><p>Nadine spent a total of just over three weeks as a named tropical or subtropical cyclone, 21.75 days, to be exact. This does not include its brief spell as a post-tropical cyclone.</p><p>Nadine's haphazard path affected The Azores not once, but twice, producing wind gusts over 50 mph in a few spots each time. Nadine strengthened to a hurricane three different times.</p><p>On Thursday, Oct. 4, the National Hurricane Center issued its final advisory on Nadine, citing the Grateful Dead's, \"What a long, strange trip it's been.\"</p><p>In sum, the NHC issued a total of 88 forecast advisories during Nadine's lifetime.</p><p>(<strong>FULL RECAP: <a href=\"/news/news/nadine-long-lasting-20120926\">Hurricane Nadine</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Tornado Debris 200 Miles Away</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn16\" /></p><p>The story here isn't so much about the subject of the photo above, but its incredible journey.</p><p>A study lead by University of Georgia associate professor, Dr. John Knox, utilized social media to track debris lofted by the violent tornadoes of the <a href=\"/storms/tornado/news/april-2011-superoutbreak-tornadoes\">April 27, 2011, outbreak</a>. </p><p>The town of Phil Campbell, Alabama, was leveled by an <a href=\"/news/weather-severe/enhanced-fujita-scale-20130206\">EF5 tornado</a> that day. </p><p>Amidst buildings swept away leaving only the slab foundation, a car wrapped around a debarked tree, and a section of highway's pavement scoured away, the tornado swept up a photo, beginning a 220-mile trip, falling back to the ground in Lenoir City, Tennessee.</p><p>According to the <a href=\"/storms/tornado/news/tornado-debris-facebook-study-20130318#/1\">Knox, et al. study</a>, a second object from Phil Campbell was deposited near Knoxville, Tennessee. </p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/storms/tornado/news/tornado-debris-facebook-study-20130318#/1\">How Facebook Was Used to Track Tornado Debris</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Sandy's Snow, Then Snow After Sandy</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn17\" /></p><p>Superstorm Sandy could take up an entire \"weird\" article by itself.</p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/news/news/sandy-recap-20121030#/2\">Daily Diary</a> | <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-sandy-pictures-photos2-20121025\">Photos</a></strong>) </p><p>First, there was the surreal sight of a mention of \"snow\" in a National Hurricane Center advisory for what was, at the time, Hurricane Sandy.</p><div>BULLETIN</div><div>HURRICANE SANDY ADVISORY NUMBER  26</div><div>NWS NATIONAL HURRICANE CENTER MIAMI FL       AL182012</div><div>500 PM EDT SUN OCT 28 2012</div><div> </div><div>...SANDY EXPECTED TO BRING LIFE-THREATENING STORM SURGE FLOODING TO</div><div>THE MID-ATLANTIC COAST...INCLUDING LONG ISLAND SOUND AND NEW YORK</div><div>HARBOR...</div><div>...WILL BRING COASTAL HURRICANE WINDS AND <strong>HEAVY APPALACHIAN SNOWS</strong>...</div><p>Cold air supplied by a southward plunge in the jet stream plus moisture hurled westward by Sandy produced <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/sandy-snowy-side-20121030\">up to 3 feet of snow in the central and southern Appalachians</a>. Blizzard conditions were reported in some areas.</p><p>Just a little more than a week after Sandy moved inland, <a href=\"https://astg2.weather.com/storms/winter/news/winter-storm-athena-remembered-infographic-20131107\" target=\"_blank\">Winter Storm Athena</a> brought snow to the Northeast coast. New York City reported 4.7 inches from the storm. More than 8 inches was reported on western Long Island near Albertson.</p><p>Images from the Jersey Shore showed snow piled on debris left behind by Sandy a little more than a week earlier.<br> </p><h3><strong>Sandy's Strange, Tragic Hook</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn18\" /><br>Many western Atlantic hurricanes curl north, then northeast safely away from the U.S. East Coast, thanks to either an impinging jet stream from the mainland, or a weaker, farther east Bermuda-Azores high.</p><p>In late October 2012, however, blocking high pressure south of Greenland and a southward jet stream dip too far west over the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley steered Sandy to a catastrophic landfall.</p><p>Late on Oct. 28, Sandy began its bizarre northwest turn toward the Jersey shore, curling almost west-northwest after landfall into Pennsylvania. </p><p>Most weather systems in the mid-latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere have at least some west-to-east motion. Tragically, Superstorm Sandy was steered off that course at exactly the wrong time.</p><p>(<strong>INTERACTIVE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-sandy-projected-path-evolution-interactive\">Evolution of Sandy's Projected Path</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>One of the Nation's Weirdest Heat Waves</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn19\" /></p><p><em>Above: An interactive map of records from the March 2012 heat wave, including record March highs, record-warm March lows, record-long March warm streaks, and record-earliest occurrences of warm weather thresholds.</em></p><p>The Upper Midwest sweated through summerlike heat in March 2012, when it was still officially winter, in what was widely considered one of the most anomalous weather events of recent memory.</p><p>Numerous cities broke all-time March records, some of them on five consecutive days.</p><p>It was so warm that <a href=\"/news/news/ten-weirdest-things-weather-20120709#/9\">some places had daily lows that were warmer than the previous record highs for those dates</a>. The warmth was so extreme that parts of Michigan rose above their average July high temperatures.</p><p>By month's end, more than 15,000 heat records had been broken - 7,755 record daily highs, and 7,517 record-warm daily lows.</p><p>Thanks to this heat wave, <a href=\"/news/news/ten-weirdest-things-weather-20120709#/8\">March was actually warmer than April</a> in over 20 cities.<br> </p><h3><strong>A Massive Hailstone</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn20\" /><br>Some of you have seen hail the size of golf balls.  </p><p>On July 23, 2010, a resident of Vivian, South Dakota, had history fall right in his yard. And it was much bigger than a golf ball.</p><p>A supercell thunderstorm littered Les Scott's yard with huge hailstones. Mr. Scott quickly stored the hailstones in his freezer.</p><p>Despite a subsequent power outage leading to some melting, an investigation by the National Weather Service in Aberdeen, South Dakota, and NOAA's Climate Extremes Committee found one of the hailstones was a new U.S. record for diameter (8 inches) and weight (1 pound, 15 ounces).  </p><p>Hailstones grow by taking a slow path through a thunderstorm's updraft while being bombarded by sheets of liquid water, freezing onto the stone. The stronger the updraft, the larger the hailstone can grow.  </p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/storms/severe/news/how-hail-forms\">How Hail Forms and Why It's Dangerous</a></strong>)</p><p>The National Weather Service estimated this hailstone was supported by updraft speeds of 160-180 mph, comparable to sustained wind speeds in a <a href=\"/safety/hurricane/news/saffir-simpson-hurricane-wind-scale\">Category 5</a> hurricane.<br> </p><h3><strong>A Hurricane in the South Atlantic Ocean</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn21\" /></p><p>Until 2004, no hurricane had ever been confirmed in the South Atlantic Ocean.</p><p>It was thought wind shear, the change in wind speed and/or direction with height, was too strong in this area to allow clusters of thunderstorms to organize around an area of low pressure to begin the process of tropical cyclogenesis.</p><p>In late March 2004, however, wind shear was low off the eastern coast of South America as an upper-level low-pressure system was sprouting thunderstorms near its center.</p><p>Making the transition to a tropical cyclone, what was later called Hurricane Catarina turned back westward, making landfall in the Santa Catarina province of Brazil as a <a href=\"/safety/hurricane/news/saffir-simpson-hurricane-wind-scale\">Category 1</a> storm on March 27, 2004.</p><p>According to <a href=\"http://www.dsr.inpe.br/geu/Rel_projetos/Relatorio_IAI_Emerson_Marcelino.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">the final summary by Marcelino et al.</a>, just over 38,000 structures were damaged and another 1,468 collapsed. Despite the freak nature of this storm, some residents evacuated from the coast. </p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/most-bizarre-hurricane-tropical-storm-cyclone-locations-20130829#/2\">Most Bizarre Tropical Cyclone Locations</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Snow Dusts a Mexican Resort</strong></h3><h3><div id=\"wxn22\" /></h3><p>The magnitude of an area of low pressure aloft in central Mexico in early March 2016 was unusually strong and cold for that area, not only for March, but anytime of year.</p><p>\"Such a large, strong upper low appears to be an unprecedented event in modern weather observations for Mexico,\" said Bob Henson in a <a href=\"http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/recordstrength-upper-low-brings-extreme-rains-to-south-us-thunders\" target=\"_blank\">wunderground.com blog</a>.</p><p>Mexico's second-most populated city, Guadalajara, even saw a coating of snow in some areas. Guadalajara is at a latitude lower than Miami and even Havana, Cuba. However, its elevation of about 5,200 feet in combination with the cold nature of the low pressure system allowed snow to fall there.</p><p>This was reportedly the first snow in Guadalajara since December 1997, another strong El Nino year. </p><p>Snow brought travel to a standstill in Durango state, and thundersnow was reported at Zacatecas (elevation 7,141 feet).<br> </p><h3><strong>\"Wrong Way\" Lenny</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn23\" /></p><p>Ã¢ÂÂWrong WayÃ¢ÂÂ Lenny was the first tropical cyclone to have an extended west-to-east track across the central and eastern Caribbean Sea in the Atlantic tropical cyclone record, according to the National Hurricane Center. </p><p>Typically, these tropical storms and hurricanes move generally the opposite direction, namely east-to-west, around the subtropical Bermuda-Azores high pressure system to its north.</p><p>However, given it was mid-late November, westerly winds aloft had already penetrated relatively far south, steering Lenny east.</p><p>This hurricane wasn't just a curiosity. St. Croix, St. Maarten/Martin, St. Lucia, Saba, Guadeloupe, Grenada among other islands, suffered heavy damage from surge flooding, rainfall flooding, and high winds.</p><p>LennyÃ¢ÂÂs name was retired from future name lists. </p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/retired-atlantic-hurricane-names\">Retired Atlantic Names</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Yes, It Does Snow in the Sunshine State</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn24\" /></p><p>Florida and snow sound like polar opposites, but it is actually a tad less rare in the Sunshine State than it sounds in north Florida.</p><p>However, on Jan. 19, 1977, residents and snowbirds escaping northern winter were shocked to see snow falling in South Florida, including Miami, for the first time in history.</p><p>Snow was reported as far south as Homestead, Florida, and was even reported in Freeport, on Grand Bahama Island. </p><p>To the north, Plant City, Florida, east of Tampa, picked up 2 inches of snow. </p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/sports-recreation/ski/news/10-shocking-snow-cities-20130118\">10 Shocking Snow Cities</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Back-to-Back Tornado Days 10 Years Apart</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn25\" /><br>On May 8, 2003, an F4 tornado tracked over some of the same areas heavily damaged by the more infamous May 3, 1999, tornado in Moore and the south Oklahoma City.</p><p>The next evening, three more tornadoes were spawned in the Oklahoma City metro area, including an F3 tornado from south of Edmond to near Luther, Oklahoma.  </p><p>This was the first time in recorded history the Oklahoma City metro area was hit by F/EF3+ or stronger tornadoes on consecutive days.</p><p>But it wouldn't be the last.</p><p>May 19-20, 2013 became the second time in recorded history to witness F/EF3+ tornadoes on consecutive days, almost exactly ten years after it was first done.</p><p>In fact, both the 2013 and 2003 events featured two tornadoes tracking from roughly the Edmond area to near Luther, as well as a Moore-to-Norman track. </p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/storms/tornado/news/oklahoma-city-moore-tornadoes-since-may3-1999\">May 3, 1999 Kicked Off a Life-Changing Stretch of Oklahoma Tornadoes</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>The Heaviest Rainstorm on Earth</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn26\" /><br>Other than the months-long soakings during the wet phase of the Asian monsoon in India, nowhere on Earth sees heavier rainstorms than <a href=\"https://weather.com/weather/radar/interactive/l/REXX0286:1:RE?layer=sat&zoom=5\">La Reunion Island</a>, a tiny French island about 500 miles east of Madagascar.  </p><p>In mid-late January 1980, Tropical Cyclone Hyacinthe stalled near the island for about two weeks, dumping up to 239.49 inches, or almost 20 feet, of rain in 15 days.</p><p>This is almost four times the average yearly rainfall in Miami.</p><p>La Reunion's volcanic peaks over 10,000 feet provide strong lift to moist air ramming into its slopes. The island is also at the climatological location where Indian Ocean tropical cyclones pivot from a west-southwest track to a more south to southeast track. Sometimes this turn occurs painfully slow.</p><p>Hyacinthe's flooding killed 25 and left 7,000 residents homeless on the island.<br> </p><h3><strong>A Tsunami Triggered By a Derecho</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn27\" /></p><p>You've heard of tsunamis triggered by earthquakes under the ocean floor, or by landslides. Did you know weather can also trigger a tsunami?</p><p>In June 2013, a squall line of severe thunderstorms producing destructive straight-line winds, known as a <a href=\"/news/news/derecho-explainer-20120612\">derecho</a>, raced from Indiana to New Jersey in 12 hours.</p><p>While responsible for over 200 reports of high winds or wind damage, it was the derecho's exit off the East Coast that was most strange.</p><p>More than 30 tide gauges along the East Coast, Bermuda and Puerto Rico recorded water level fluctuations consistent with a tsunami, yet no earthquake was recorded. The so-called \"meteotsunami\" was believed to be caused by the derecho itself.</p><p>Unlike recent destructive tsunamis in Japan and Indonesia, this meteotsunami's peak amplitude was just under one foot above sea level. However, one six-foot wave swept three people off rocks at Barnegat Inlet, New Jersey.<br> </p><h3><strong>Arkansas Snow ... in May!</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn28\" /></p><p>Early May in northwest Arkansas typically features daytime highs in the 70s and morning lows in the 50s.</p><p>In 2013, snow fell for the first time in state history in May, thanks to <a href=\"/forecast/news/winter-storm-achilles-20130430\">Winter Storm Achilles</a>.</p><p>It wasn't just a dusting either. Up to 5 inches of snow was measured in Decatur, Arkansas.</p><p>Achilles also produced the first May flakes of snow on record in Tulsa, Oklahoma, and the latest snow on record in Springfield, Missouri.</p><p>Achilles was the May snowstorm of record in Omaha, Neb. (3.1 inches), Des Moines, Iowa (6.9 inches), Eau Claire, Wis. (9.3 inches) and Rochester, Minn. (14.3 inches). </p><p>Less than two weeks later, Omaha soared to 101 degrees on May 14, its hottest day on record so early in the season.<br> </p><h3><strong>January Atlantic Hurricane</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn29\" /><br><em>Above: </em><em>Animation of GOES-East satellite imagery from Jan. 10 to 14, 2016 shows the development of Hurricane Alex in the eastern Atlantic Ocean. (Credit: NASA/NOAA GOES Project)</em></p><p>The 2016 Atlantic hurricane season got off to a very early start.</p><p>Hurricane Alex became the first January Atlantic hurricane since 1955, only the second Atlantic hurricane to form in January (the other was in 1938), and the strongest January Atlantic hurricane on record (85 mph peak winds).</p><p>What's more, Alex made a landfall in the island of Terceira in The Azores, a group of Portuguese islands located 800 to 900 miles west of Portugal's mainland. Wind gusts over 50 mph were measured in The Azores as the center sliced through.</p><p>(<strong>FULL RECAP: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-alex-atlantic-ocean-azores\">Hurricane Alex</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Monthly Global Temperature Record Streak</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn30\" /><br>As of the time of this column, the Earth's temperatures were on an unsettling record streak.</p><p>March 2016 marked the 11th consecutive month global temperatures set records for that particular month in two separate databases, NOAA and the Japanese Meteorological Agency (JMA).</p><p>NOAA said this was the longest stretch of months in a row where the earth has set a new monthly temperature record dating to 1880.</p><p>What's more, Earth's global temperatures in March 2016 were the most abnormally warm on record for any month, according to NOAA, for the second month in a row.</p><p>Through March 2016, <a href=\"/news/climate/news/record-warmest-march-global-2016\">nine of the 10 largest monthly warm anomalies in the 125-year JMA analysis record have occurred from May 2015 through March 2016</a>.</p><p>A <a href=\"/news/climate/news/el-nino-ties-record-january-2016\">record-tying El NiÃÂ±o</a> certainly played a role, but warm anomalies were found in many areas of the globe in 2015 and early 2016, particularly in the Arctic.<br> </p><h3><strong>Snow Following a Destructive Tornado</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn31\" /></p><p>The cruel reality about early-spring or late fall tornadoes is that Ol' Man Winter can follow.</p><p>A blanket of light snow fell just days after the March 2, 2012, <a href=\"/storms/tornado/news/enhanced-fujita-scale-20130206\">EF3</a> tornado ravaged West Liberty, Kentucky.</p><p>A cooperative observer just northwest of town measured almost 5 inches of snow, making the clean-up more difficult in this east Kentucky town.</p><p>Perhaps the most egregious example occurred on Nov. 11, 1911, when an F4 tornado in Janesville, Wisconsin, was followed just hours later by bitter cold air and blizzard conditions as survivors were still digging through the rubble.</p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/sports-recreation/ski/news/5-extreme-temperature-drops-20130118#/1\">5 Incredible Temperature Swings</a></strong>)</p><p>Interestingly enough, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/akrherz/status/437246320365953024/photo/1\" target=\"_blank\">there have also been times where a county is covered both by a tornado or severe thunderstorm warning and a blizzard warning</a>. </p><p>This typically happens when a very strong low-pressure system in winter or early spring first triggers severe thunderstorms over an area in its warm sector, then wraps heavy snow and high winds the next day or sooner over that same area.<br> </p><h3><strong>Medicanes</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn32\" /></p><p>Can tropical storms, even hurricanes, form in the Mediterranean Sea?</p><p>One argument for so-called \"medicanes\" is the appearance of some recent storms via satellite resembling small hurricanes, including an eye. </p><p>The most vivid recent example of this was in January 1995. National Hurricane Center senior hurricane specialist <a href=\"http://www.mindspring.com/~jbeven/intr0008.htm\" target=\"_blank\">Dr. Jack Beven chronicled this impressive storm, including satellite imagery</a>.</p><p>In early November 2011, another low over the Mediterranean Sea appeared to have transitioned to at least a subtropical storm, if not a tropical storm. NOAA/NESDIS designated this Tropical Storm 01M, also called \"Rolf\", on Nov. 7.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1983\" target=\"_blank\">Weather Underground's Dr. Jeff Masters, however, noted water temperatures near the cyclone were quite cold, on the order of 63 degrees Fahrenheit (17C)</a>, well below the typical threshold needed to maintain a tropical cyclone (usually around 79 degrees Fahrenheit).</p><p>Nevertheless, the storm made landfall in southeast France, producing up to two feet of rain, triggering major flooding in parts of France, Spain, and Italy. Twelve were killed.</p><p>(<strong>MORE: <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/most-bizarre-hurricane-tropical-storm-cyclone-locations-20130829\">Strangest Locations Tropical Cyclones Have Formed</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Superstorm 1993</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn33\" /><br>One of the most extreme extratropical storms in U.S. history, this mid-March 1993 storm had it all. </p><p>A storm surge resembling that of a hurricane along Florida's Gulf Coast in what was still winter. About as close to whiteout conditions as you'll ever see on Peachtree Street in Atlanta.</p><p>Here are just some of the other incredible highlights:</p><ul><li>Six-foot snow drifts in Birmingham, Alabama</li><li>Up to 6 inches of snow in the Florida Panhandle</li><li>Up to 14 foot drifts in Virginia</li><li>Thousands isolated by heavy snow in the Southeast</li><li>A 12-foot storm surge in Taylor County, Florida.</li><li>270 killed in 13 states from Florida to Maine</li><li>$5.5 billion estimated damage (1993 dollars)</li><li>20,000 homes damaged in Florida</li><li>3 million power outages</li><li>All major East Coast airports closed</li><li><a href=\"/news/news/derecho-explainer-20120612\">Derecho</a> raced across Florida and Cuba with 109 mph wind gust at the Dry Tortugas and a 100 mph gust in Havana, Cuba.</li></ul><p>(<strong>WATCH: <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=44cHhoU0mwc\" target=\"_blank\">The Weather Channel coverage of Superstorm 1993</a></strong>)<br> </p><h3><strong>Two Hurricanes in Six Days</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn34\" /></p><p>Bermuda experienced an unprecedented double whammy in 2014, as hurricanes made landfall there just six days apart: Hurricane Fay on Oct. 12, followed by Hurricane Gonzalo on Oct. 18.</p><p>The island had never been affected by two named storms so close together in time, let alone seen both of them make landfall on the tiny cluster of islands, which have a combined land area of less than 21 square miles, about three-fifths the size of Manhattan.</p><p><a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/fay-bermuda-impacts-20141012\">Fay was unexpectedly damaging</a>, knocking out power to the vast majority of BermudaÃ¢ÂÂs residents.</p><p>Cleanup had to be expedited as <a href=\"/storms/hurricane/news/hurricane-gonzalo-bermuda-impacts-20141019\">Gonzalo quickly followed</a>; Gonzalo was BermudaÃ¢ÂÂs strongest and most damaging hurricane since Fabian in 2003. Gonzalo left behind an estimated $200 million to $400 million in damage.<br> </p><h3><strong>14 Years of Rain in 24 Hours</strong></h3><p><div id=\"wxn35\" /></p><p>Chile's Atacama Desert is one of the world's driest places. The port city of Antofagasta picks up a mere 0.07 inches of rain a year.</p><p>In late March 2015, Antofagasta picked up almost an inch of rain in 24 hours -- 0.96 inches, to be precise.</p><p>While this may not sound like much, as senior digital meteorologist Nick Wiltgen noted, \"Without soil and plant cover to help absorb rainfall, it just runs off instantly as torrents of water.\"</p><p>Unfortunately, this proved deadly.</p><p>The torrential rain flooded the Copiapo River, claiming at least nine lives. Chile's Deputy Interior Minister Mahmud Aleuy called the flooding \"the worst rain disaster to fall on the north in 80 years.\"</p><p>(<strong>FULL RECAP: <a href=\"/news/news/chile-floods-atacama-desert-storms-copiapo-river\">Killer Floods Soak Chilean Desert</a></strong>)</p><p>\"That extreme rainfall in South America wasn't just from an isolated thunderstorm, it was with a larger-scale pattern, they key being a very strong ridge of high pressure aloft, as has been the case with so many precipitation and temperature extremes in recent years,\" said <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/twcstuostro\" target=\"_blank\">Stu Ostro</a>, senior meteorologist at The Weather Channel, in an  email.</p><p>\"This may be the most extraordinary one so far, given that it involves both one of the world's driest locations and the coldest continent (referring to a <a href=\"/news/news/antarctica-all-time-warm-temperature-record\">possible Antarctica all-time record high set within days of this event</a>), and at the same time no less, in the Southern Hemisphere.\" </p><div><em>Jonathan Erdman is a senior meteorologist at weather.com and has been an incurable weather geek since a tornado narrowly missed his childhood home in Wisconsin at age 7.</em></div><div><table align=\"left\" border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"width:500px;\"><tbody><tr><td style=\"text-align: left; vertical-align: top;\"><div id=\"wxn36\" /></td><td style=\"text-align: left; vertical-align: top;\"><div id=\"wxn37\" "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/barrowobservatory.jpg?v=at&w=1280&h=720&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "200" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/barrowobservatory.jpg?v=at&w=200&h=200&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0" , "400" : "https://dsx.weather.com//util/image/w/barrowobservatory.jpg?v=at&w=400&h=400&api=7db9fe61-7414-47b5-9871-e17d87b8b6a0"} , "body" : "<p><div id=\"wxn0\" /></p><p>Snow is melting in Barrow, Alaska, earlier than it ever has since scientists at NOAAÃ¢ÂÂs Barrow Observatory began recording it.</p><p>Staff at the observatory reported <a href=\"http://www.noaa.gov/arctic-set-for-record-breaking-melt\" target=\"_blank\">snowmelt occurred May 13</a>, the earliest snowmelt date in 73 years of record-keeping, beating the previous mark set in 2002 by a full 10 days.</p><p><div id=\"wxn1\" /></p><p>At 320 miles north of the Arctic Circle, Barrow is usually one of the last places in the United States to lose snow cover. But the early melting follows a record-setting winter that saw temperatures average more than 11 degrees above normal for the 49th State, shattering the previous record set in 2015. </p><p>On May 14, Fairbanks topped out at <a href=\"https://weather.com/news/weather/news/fairbanks-alaska-warmer-denver-cleveland-boston\" target=\"_blank\">a record-breaking 82 degrees</a>, surpassing the warmest readings that Lower 48 cities such as Boston, Cleveland and Denver have seen to that point in 2016.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"https://weather.com/science/environment/news/arctic-sea-ice-near-record-low-climate-central\" target=\"_blank\">Arctic Sea Ice Is in Record Low Territory, Again</a>)</strong></p><p>According to weather.com meteorologist Brian Donegan, only two other times since 1904 has it been 82 degrees or warmer in Fairbanks that early in the season. The earliest Fairbanks ever topped 82 degrees was May 10, 1995 (84 degrees), followed by the second earliest the following day, May 11, 1995 (88 degrees).</p><p>The record temps are also taking their toll on Arctic sea ice. The annual Arctic sea ice maximum hit its lowest level ever recorded. That marks the second straight year that the winter maximum ice extent set a record low.</p><p><div id=\"wxn2\" /></p><p>Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve never seen such <a href=\"https://weather.com/science/environment/news/arctic-sea-ice-hits-record-low-again-climate-central\" target=\"_blank\">a warm, crazy winter in the Arctic</a>,Ã¢ÂÂ Mark Serreze, director of the National Snow and Ice Data Center, told Climate Central. Ã¢ÂÂThe heat was relentless.Ã¢ÂÂ</p><p>Arctic sea ice hit its maximum extent for the winter on March 24, when it averaged 5.607 million square miles, Climate Central reports. That beat last yearÃ¢ÂÂs record low of 5.612 million square miles, set on Feb. 25, 2015, by 5,000 square miles or just a bit smaller than the area of Connecticut.</p><p><strong>(MORE: <a href=\"https://weather.com/science/space/news/f17-satellite-loses-communication\" target=\"_blank\">Scientists Lose Crucial Tool to Record Arctic Ice Loss</a>)</strong></p><p>Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs like a trainwreck you canÃ¢ÂÂt look away from,Ã¢ÂÂ wildlife biologist George Divoky said in a NOAA release. Ã¢ÂÂYou never know what youÃ¢ÂÂre going to see and this yearÃ¢ÂÂs as big a mystery as any.Ã¢ÂÂ</p><p><div id=\"wxn3\" /></p>" , "flags" : { "Facebook" : true , "Intranet" : false , "TV App" : false , "Twitter" : true , "YouTube" : true , "Google+" : true , "Big Web" : true , "Little Web" : true , "Mobile Apps" : true , "orig_source" : "Reboot"} , "wxnodes" : [ { "id" : "wxn0" , "schema_version" : "1.1.12" , "type" : "wxnode_video" , "align" : "" , "options" : [ "show_descriptions"] , "assetid" : "" , "clipid" : "087544e8-bb1f-4fb3-8156-60c716a6b782" , "collection" : "" , "collection_name" : "" , "playlist_type" : "assets"} , { "id" : "wxn1" , "type" : "wxnode_internal_image" , "links" : [ ] , "align" : "left" , "assetid" : "1e7645ab-7440-4b54-8a03-e0aa61f54a5a" , "sizecode" : "inset" , "credit" : "NOAA" , "linkurl" : "" , "synopsis" : "Scientists at NOAA's Barrow Observatory recorded the first snowmelt on May 13, a full 10 days earlier, than ever before seen.
